posts.name: Anderson Hall
posts.cooked:
We’ve been having some issues with some drive commands, such as turning the chassis with the l/r triggers, and a “boost mode” button.

These commands work whenever we run them off of SmartDashboard, (the commands only change a variable, so the isFinished field is true for the “boost mode” command). However, when we try to bind these commands to a button on the driver joystick, the drivetrain maintains it’s current state, i.e. will continue running motors after the button is pressed as if the same inputs are being sent, even when they aren’t.

Meaning, when we press the “boost button” the robot will no longer respond to the default drive command.

When run in Shuffleboard, the command ends instantly (because of the isFinished field being true) and the drivetrain is responsive.

Any ideas on how to make this work with a button?

Also, is there any way to run a command whenever an axis on a controller ≠ 0?

code

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: I’d suggest that “boost mode” doesn’t need to be a command at all.  instead, add a Boolean to your subsystem drive method, and pass the button state in robot container.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
There are many ways to handle this, but the most elegant way to do it is to have your default command handle the boost. Really, boosting is a characteristic of your drive command, not your subsystem (unless the drivetrain has a physical boost, like a shifting gearbox.)

If boost is on the subsystem, you need to make sure all of your commands handle it. For example, if you decide to implement any kind of driver assist command that takes over the drivetrain, it will need to make sure boost mode is set properly when it starts and ends, or things won’t work right.

The easiest way to run a command when an axis exceeds a threshold is to use the CommandJoystick class instead of Joystick . It has this capability built in. Another way to do it is with a custom Trigger with a BooleanSupplier that checks the axis value.

posts.name: Matt Pizzimenti
Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: @truher This may work in this case, but you essentially have a command that uses the drivetrain subsystem without “requiring” it. That will be problematic if there’s another command running that doesn’t expect this boost, like running a PathPlanner path. It’s best to only have commands that require the subsystem manipulate its state since they don’t know what other command might be in control of the subsystem.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: ah, let me clarify: I’m not suggesting that the subsystem have any sort of state that represents boost mode at all.  I’m suggesting that the drive method simply scale the driver input based on a Boolean argument.  it’s literally just another thing the driver is indicating on the controller, not a state of the system.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: Oh I see, that makes sense, I misunderstood. That would be just putting the scaling into the drive method. Then I think our solutions are complementary. I’m suggesting the command handle it, and you’re saying the command could pass a boolean to the drive method to scale the input.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Alternatively, you could schedule a different drive command which scales the inputs differently.  This would let you parameterize the drive command with immutable/constant scaling parameters instead of a supplier.

posts.name: Anderson Hall
posts.cooked: I’ve tried creating a boolean inside of the drive subsystem, but actually changing the speed in the drive command hasn’t worked.

posts.name: Anderson Hall
posts.cooked: We have a default drive command setup, but the robot still likes to not respond to changes in joysticks whenever we run a command that somehow effects the drive command/subsystem

posts.name: Anderson Hall
posts.cooked:
We did try this: We “spoofed” the joystick values given to the default drive command by multiplying them by a ratio (0.8), so in theory the speed would cap at 0.8 of max.

This didn’t work and had the same issues with the other attempts, that the drivetrain would continue the most recent command and not update

posts.name: Anderson Hall
posts.cooked:
Is this what you mean for the axis? image 769×53 5.01 KB

image 769×53 5.01 KB

image 769×53 5.01 KB

(Also, sorry for the excess of replies, only realized I could’ve done it in one reply after I sent 4 replies)

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
the reason that’s happening is that you’re using a command that only does some of the driving work.  the choices here are:

use two commands.  one for default speed, one for boost mode.  they’re almost exactly the same except for the speed multiplier.  both “require” the subsystem, so when you schedule the boost, it cancels the default, and when the boost ends, the default starts again.

use one default command, which handles boosting.

all these commands would need to call “subsystem.drive” in “command.execute.”

what’s happening now is that your default command is calling “drive” but your “boost” command does not, so the subsystem just keeps obeying the most-recent “drive” call.

posts.name: Anderson Hall
posts.cooked:
That makes sense.

Would calling the default drive command in the “end” field fix this?

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
the command scheduler will take care of running the default command.

i think if you want to keep the idea where the “boost” command simply changes the subsystem state, then you should use “trigger.ontrue” instead of “whiletrue” and your SetDriveRatio command should do all the work in initialize().

that way the scheduler will run the boost command for one cycle and then go back to the default command 0.02 sec later.
posts.edit_reason: Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.

posts.name: Anderson Hall
posts.cooked:
I’ve already tried changing the trigger from .ontrue to .whiletrue, didn’t work, same thing happened.

Wouldn’t SetDriveRatio being in initialize only work the first time the command is run, and not in consecutive callings?

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: no, the “initialize” method is called each time the command is scheduled, i.e. each time the button is pressed.
posts.edit_reason: Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.

posts.name: Anderson Hall
posts.cooked:
Oh, I always thought that init would only run the command the first time the command is called, not every time it’s called but not every 20ms…

Thanks

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
That is what I mean by axis, but your usage looks a little off. I pulled down your code, and I see you are using XBox controllers, not joysticks. In that case, I recommend you use CommandXboxController . You should also only create one instance of XBoxController or CommandXboxController per device (port), so create it once and reuse it.

Change the type of your your driver and/or operator controllers to CommandXboxController

Instead of needing to create JoystickButton objects and binding buttons by ID, you can use trigger methods with meaningful names:

Finally, what you were actually asking about. CommandXboxController has a couple helpful methods for creating a trigger based on an axis. You can use axisGreaterThan with an axis number (I prefer using the constants from XBoxController.Axis instead of magic numbers), or you can use the methods like rightTrigger() :

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
I will try to give you one option here that’s fully fleshed out. There are lots of different options, and I think you’re getting lost. The core of the problem is that only one command can use a subsystem at a time.

The simplest option is to have a single command that handles both regular speed and boost mode.

Delete SetDriveRatio command.

Delete DriveSubsystem.setSpeedRatio() .

Make kMaxSpeedMetersPerSecond final so it it truly a constant that represents the drivetrain’s top speed.

Finally, update your default command to handle the button press and increase/decrease the max speed. Since you have the command inline, it could look like this (don’t forget the addition of curly braces):
